I am surprised to see people excoriating the coach and criticizing the quality of midfield play.

The U.S. back line had terrible positioning and ball handling errors in every game. In this game both goals came in situations in which one extended Ghanaian forward beat two U.S. fullbacks before beating Howard.

Meanwhile the U.S. strikers came up empty while repeatedly being set up in front of the opponents goal—usually by Donovan.

The U.S. team needed something like two good defenders and a striker to get to the next level. It was a great effort by the mid-fielders and the forwards (and Howard) to carry the team this far. This wasn't the mid-field's best game but over all they had a great tournament.

As for Bradley, the only question in my mind is whether there were young defenders left at home who he should have developed.

The bottom line is that it was a great effort by a team with some glaring weaknesses and little depth. That sounds like pretty decent coaching.

The USA may well win the World Cup in the next 20 years, but just how far there is to go before soccer becomes a part of your culture is demonstrated by the way you describe the ball "merrily" rolling :-)

When a nation of some 300 million can only muster a striker like Altidore who is apparently a Haitian dual citizen then it is a miracle that they are even in the World Cup. He was the worst striker of all the teams. Always with a gigantic heavy lead first touch and could not make anyone intelligent decision. With a thing like that at the front, then what gives.

He is only 20 but he is all 20 years worth of awful mess and he could have won all games if he had any sense as to what he is doing. If he is too young, then where is the old guy that can score. This simply proves that in Yankee land, only 3rd and 4th tier athletes come out to play soccer. That is, guys that can not make the other 4or 5 major sports, including college sports which are semiprofessional. A player with the power of Gyan and speed combination, would be playing oneof the speed and soft touch positions in another sport, maybe cornerback or receiver in American football but never comes out to play soccer. That is the system. The real top kid athletes are not playing soccer as they are in Europe and the rest of the world.

And this might take another 100 yrs. take another 100 plus years.

My daughter just returned from a semester in Ghana three weeks ago. Pretty happy times in my household, too, if for no other reason that I couldn't stand Ian Darke and John Harkes' naked homerism. They have been unlisteneable. If you want a 'hollywood ending,' go see "Victory." The World Cup is much more, as America's foremost war criminal and soccer aficionado Henry Kissinger would say, 'realpolitik.'

While it was a bit disappointing to stay up until 5 AM when I have to work the next day to see us lose, I'm still proud of our side. All I wanted from the beginning was to make it to the elimination round, which we did with flourish despite terrible calls against us. Their play was marked by hard work and a refusal to give up; truly inspirational. They should be proud of themselves and the recognition they gained during their time at the World Cup.

@ianicol: In four matches in this tournament, the US shipped five goals. I would submit to you that all but Gyan's match winner today were PRIMARILY attrbutable to poor midfield play:
Vs. England, Ricardo Clark loses track of Gerrard, who is all alone to take the wall pass and use the outside of the foot to flick it past Howard.
Vs. Solvenia, Birsa was allowed to drift behind Bradley into acres of space, unaccounted for by his midfield counterpart. He was allowed to wind up and hit a screamer past Howard. Here I disagree with my friend Lazar (LT) who would like to attribute this one to Onyewu. Onyewu was late to arrive, but the defense is not generally responsible for shots taken from 30 yards. Michael Bradley's bad right there. The second Slovene goal was again created by a midfielder with the time and space to pick out the runner who could beat the offside trap. Onyewu botched the trap, but for me this one was 60-40% midfield-defense culpability.
Vs. Ghana, Ricardo Clark gave up the ball with one small jostle. Boateng was able to ram it down our throats. For this one, I'd assess culpability as 35% midfield for giving it away and no cover from Bradley, the partner in the middle, 35% defense (DeMerit) for failing to challenge Boateng, and 30% to Howard for giving up his near post.

I agree with you wholeheartedly about the problems in defense and on the forward line.

But I will continue to excoriate BB for several reasons:
Why is the team so unready to play from the outset. Four matches, three in which we conceded within 13 minutes (and a tenth minute crossbar smash from Algeria, too. Not only that, but we REPEATED the fatal mistake in extra time. Route 1 on a punt right between the two central defenders in the first three minutes of XT? NOT ACCEPTABLE. Responsible party for the team being ready to play is Bob Bradley.
After experimenting with midfield partners for his son, starting with Ricardo Clark, then having a nightmare from Torres, and finally using Edu for the second half vs. Slovenia and vs. Algeria, why, oh why was he back tinkering with Clark again. Giveaway for a goal, a yellow card that might well have been red (it was a leg breaker) and subbed off in 30 minutes. What more proof do you need that BB screwed the pooch? You can tinker with the lineup in friendlies (there were three in the last month) and in the group stage, but how can you not have a lineup set once the knockout phase begins? In BBs behalf, I was one of Bornstein's harshest critics, but BBs faith in him was rewarded. He was solid and good in the last two matches. But on the other hand, he brought and used Onyewu who was clearly unfit, but steadfastly refused to take a flyer on Charlie Davies. In my days of coaching youth soccer, I would always tell my friends that a weak forward can't kill you, but a weak defender can kill you deader than Elvis. Could Davies, despite his physical condition, really have been as ineffectual as Findley was? A team with aspirations to the quarters or semis of the WC has to have a forward who can bury the chance that Findley, off the Ghanaian midfield turnover, put right off of Kingson's foot. DeMerit is a nice player, but he is, as they say, punching well above his weight. He's on Watford, a middle of the second division side. So ianicol, in sumary, my issues with BB are no more fundamental than game preparation, squad choices, tactical blundering and evaluation of personnel he has used. Other than that, I'm fine with him. Cheers!

I'm currently doing research in journalism and conflict and have recently spoken to many journalists on this topic.  Sometimes embedding is the only way to get a story or stay safe.  I am finding the predominant view is that 'good journalism' can still surface against the odds. A lot of this is dependent on the journalists' own organisation and training  but also crucially on personal principles and ethics.

Mr. Hersh's argument would hold true in WWII, the Korean War, Vietnam and any trouble outside of Middle Eastern conflict zones. Then, a reporter had a great chance of not being killed just for being a Westerner. The people we are fighting in Afghanistan, and the ones who are left fighting in Iraq, do not value life as we do.  They wish to turn the whole world into a 10th century empire. As such, they will kill anyone who does not espouse their message, most especially reporters. The number of slain Iraqi (and other Arabic) reporters is staggering. For a Western journalist the only way to get a decent look at the war and the people is to embed.  Yes, you run the risk of favoring your escorts over "the enemy" but I have read several accounts where embedded reporters were able to talk to people far away from the "Green Zones". In the quiet villages, they could talk to regular people, with out fear. The few that I have read said they would never have been able to do that alone.

The whole McCrystal incident demonstrates some real problems in this Afghan war:
- The incident brings to light the rupture between the civilians and the military. The U.S,, as a nation, is merely inconvenienced but not sacrificing for a winnable war- unlike WW2. Furthermore, the lack of connectivity of all-volunteer U.S. army with the public encourages such behavior of arrogant generals.
- That McCrystal was frustrated by being constrained by the counterinsurgency policy that appears to be more focused on nation-building rather than defeating the enemy. Although he endorsed the policy, winning the hearts of the people through building of utilities, roads, schools, and agriculture productivity takes tremendous skills which the military may not be suited for.
- That the entire war may be doomed when Karzai is seen as a corrupt tribal leader rather than a true nation-leader. How can the Afghan people have respect for the U.S. and its goals when they have none for Karzai?
- That the objective of eliminating the Al-Qaeda is lost when Al-Qaeda is operating out of Pakistan and its frontier area. Both Karzai and Pakistan are cutting deals with the Taliban as we speak. If we cannot eliminate them, how can we hope to rein-in the Taliban? The war's objective must be to neutraize Al-Qaeda rather than re-invent Afghanistan in our image. Lao Tzu was right over 2,000 years ago - do not get caught up in debilitating wars far from home. Declare victory and get out.

I think that this series will be revealing and informative. Both sides are true in the embedding argument. I agree with Seymour Hersh, but it is necessary to report the news, and embedding, while it was designed for some news-related purpose, is also news itself. I have been reading the New York Times since 1965, I read it when I went into the Marines in the Vietnam War, I read it when I finished my degree during Watergate. The New York Times keeps outdoing itself, and this series will uncover issues with the way we see this new kind of war that was started by two people who ignored Santayana's aphorism, "Those who cannot remember the past are condemned to repeat it."
But yes, Seymour Hersh is correct, that there is a problematical bias in some reporting when it comes from sources collocated with military units. This bias is not only driven by embedding, but also by an idealism of first-time war reporters. But we should be able to analyze this reporting against other sources to uncover the subtle issues in this complex war. I miss Drew Middleton's military analyses and this is what's required now.
As news sources collapse and yield to nonsensical blog opinion, there is pressure on professional news organizations to provide the analysis that intelligent people need to build an understanding of Asian military tactics and geopolitics.

While this is certainly an indictment of the main stream media and even Obama's team, the real bottom line to all of this drama is that Obama now has a unique opportunity to end the Afghanistan fiasco.

Gen. David Petraeus should do what Gen. Stanley A. McChrystal could never do: review the situation and determine that our objective in Afghanistan is neither valid or reasonable. For a strategy we have two choices: 1) pull out now and save countless lives or 2) do another 'surge' where we add at least 250000 troops and take the country by force, literally running roughshod over the populace.

Of course we can't pull off such a surge so we should leave. It's obvious we can't carry on as we have for the last ten years.

Obama will have determined that he fulfilled his campaign promise to wage the 'just' war but that his top generals have determined there is nothing to 'justify' more killing of our young brave men and women who have volunteered to protect our liberty but not chase ghosts of Bush and Cheney's nightmares while doing the bidding of petulant military general demigods.

And therein lies our hope: That Obama will get us out now and forever from these foreign follies that get us nowhere, but earn us the enmity of the rest of the world.

If he does that, then McChrystal will have accomplished more as a wimpy whiner than he could ever accomplish macho military maven.

Thanks for a brilliantly written and hard-hitting analysis of where we are and where we have been. Unfortunately, it completes the story of the failure of every institution in our society to see and tell the truth and react sensibly to it. Last to fall were our well-trained military and our mainstream print media, which some of us had hoped would actually practice journalism a bit longer than TV.

What have we got left? Congress is insanely partisan, dysfunctional, and mostly bought. The military won't tell the truth except in closed hearings. The financial sector is still fighting meaningful reform and hoping that derivatives will insure its failures at others' expense. Our energy sector is bent on exploiting fossil fuels until they run dry or poison our plant, whichever comes first. The Catholic Church protected pedophiles. Many Jews support an Israeli settlement policy indistinguishable from slow-motion conquest. Science still works, but no one pays it much heed, either on global warming or on how to stop the BP Oil Spill. And now we know our media failed us not just going into the war in Iraq, but in escalating Afghanistan, too.

Maybe it's time for a new religion. We surely need something to believe in.

Before Vietnam, our war record had no blemish: we had never lost a major conflict. But we scratched our brand new car in Vietnam, and now we should just drive it. We should use a cold, clear-headed cost-benefit analysis at every stage of every conflict. If we do that, we should know that the costs of remaining in Afghanistan after nine relatively fruitless years outweigh any conceivable benefit. A Taliban victory is virtually inevitable, so we should do our best, on the way out, to make sure the best Taliban win. (No, they are not all alike.)

The task of reforming and remaking every institution in our society lies before us. It will take decades. If we are very clever and very lucky, we might change enough to avoid becoming a third-world nation in record time. Any war now, except one for literal national survival, is a distraction and an expense we don't need.

Although I vehemently opposed escalation of the American ground presence in Afghanistan, in McChrystal's defense it need be noted that he was asked by Obama to prosecute an ugly losing war, while Obama permitted senior administration officials freely to question its goals and legitimacy. Was it fair to allow these administration officials to undercut openly McChrystal's thankless mission and not to expect any expression of anger, offense or resentment from the general and his staff? These are not saints; they are soldiers. Obama is the commander in chief, and he made a decision, albeit the wrong one. In fairness to the U.S. armed forces sent by Obama to Afghanistan, was it not his responsibility also to demand that Biden, et al, refrain from public expressions of skepticism? Although highly educated, Obama was never schooled in management or leadership, and we are witnessing the results.

Decades ago, when Communist Cuba wanted to expand its influence in impoverished countries, one of its core actions was to send many doctors and teachers. That strategy worked far better than anything that the U.S. has tried anywhere, and it must rank as one of the most cost-effective. We, on the other hand, have spent hundreds of billions of dollars in Afghanistan, long after most of Al Qaeda fled --- to send tens of thousands of troops with often inadequate cultural sensitivity and restraint, to drop bombs and fire missiles and cause civilian casualties, in the process generating tremendous animosity in an insular society based so strongly on religion and family and tribal allegiances. Wonder "why do they hate us?". News flash: for the most part, it AIN'T "because they hate our freedom".

We cannot "win" in Afghanistan, in the traditional military sense of that term to mean vanquish and control. There are many reasons why Afghanistan is known as "The Graveyard of Empires". The British came to know that, as did eventually the Soviets. How long will it take the U.S. to learn? The methods of insurgency change over the centuries, but they share a remarkable cost-effectiveness. Nowadays, a $3 million Stryker armored vehicle can be destroyed, and its occupants killed or maimed, with an IED made from a leftover artillery shell and a $5 remote control. The clinical phrase "asymmetric warfare" doesn't even begin to describe what the U.S. is facing there.

The only way for the U.S. to "win" (aside from the preferable "declare victory and get out") is to redefine that word "win" as "perhaps influence", throttle way back on attempts at a military victory, and direct nearly all of our Afghanistan effort (and spending) to infrastructure improvement --- both physical and social services --- in areas that are already secure. Transform those areas into (relative) paradises, and thereby make the population on the outside dissatisfied with what they have, comparatively, in areas controlled by our opponents. (To those Americans who wish to focus on fighting, who might say that no areas are secure enough for an infrastructure improvement strategy --- despite nearly nine years of U.S. involvement --- well, you've just made the case for leaving, unconditionally, right now).

To a very large extent (but with appropriate financial oversight to minimize corruption), these projects should be designed and built by the people of Afghanistan, not high-priced Western consultants and contractors. (Don't tell me that there are no Afghani civil engineers or public health professionals; such a claim is Western-centric arrogance). Beyond being vastly more cost-effective, Afghani design and construction would give the people there an important psychological and economic stake in the enterprise. If their national or provincial governments can't or won't move infrastructure projects along, empower local development councils to do so.

Of course, I don't expect any part of such a strategy to be adopted, since we're not even willing to concern ourselves with needed infrastructure and social services on U.S. soil. Plus, the U.S. military-industrial complex will vigorously fight any decrease in spending for the war machine, and most politicians both Democrat and Republican remain its enthusiastic lackeys, striving to outdo each other in feeding the beast. Some politicians (very wrongly) believe in American militarism as a desirable course of action; others are simply giving value for money to their corporate contributors; still others are just gutless wonders who prefer to sacrifice the infrastructure --- and future --- of this country rather than risk their own political careers by bringing sanity to our military spending and explaining to their constituents why American militarism-as-usual can't continue. And in the end times of the American Empire, too many Americans would rather cling to a paranoid yet arrogant imperial militarism than face the facts about how the world works and the limits of our power, and our important domestic problems that should take precedence.

Where is the leadership that we need?

"The gaping discrepancy between Emanuel’s upbeat assessment and the reality on the ground went unremarked because absolutely no one was paying attention. Everyone is now. That, at least, gives us reason to hope that the president’s first bold move to extricate America from the graveyard of empires won’t be his last. "

What bold move, Mr. Rich? Moving generals around like the deck chairs on the Titanic? It seems to me that President Obama's take on this latest incident is for digging his heels into the tar sands of the war mentality that reveals a demented mindset issuing from the Pentagon.

The civilian population of our country is being directed by the corporate military power structure embedded in our nation and the results are beginning to become apparent. From outragious destruction of our environment by unregulated Oil companies to the unnecessary bloodshed in Afghanistan of our troops and its civilian population along with equal damage to our financial empire, we seem to be paralyzed like cobras being sung to in India.

We had better wake up rapidly and begin to recognize the reality we are avoiding. Come November, the results of Democratic malfeasance will become clear with losses and change to the right wing mindset that will continue the march to self destruction. One must read the impassioned and educated comments to Mr. Herbert's recent columns about the necessity of getting out of the Afghanistan quagmire in order to recognize the growing anger of the voters.

Your hopes for President Obama, which you mention in other columns, are wasted rhetoric. He and his advisors do not have a clue to what is happening to our nation and will change nothing basic as a result. Mere cosmetic touches are becoming more lipstick on a pig and such surface changes no longer suffice.

If only one could say that the 36 hours that shook Washington was more than a mere blip on the radar screen. More shocks are on their way.
